subject: catecholamine
text: The molecular basis for the aberrant catecholamine responsiveness of the adenylate cyclase of adrenocortical carcinoma 494 was explored.

subject: adenylate cyclase
text: The adenylate cyclase of this corticosteroid-producing, transplanted, adrenal cancer of the rat was stimulated not only by adrenocorticotropic hormone and fluoride, but also by the f8-adrenergic agonist, isoproterenol.

subject: adenylate cyclase
text: The adenylate cyclase of this corticosteroid-producing, transplanted, adrenal cancer of the rat was stimulated not only by adrenocorticotropic hormone and fluoride, but also by the f8-adrenergic agonist, isoproterenol.

subject: adenylate cyclase
text: The adenylate cyclase of this corticosteroid-producing, transplanted, adrenal cancer of the rat was stimulated not only by adrenocorticotropic hormone and fluoride, but also by the f8-adrenergic agonist, isoproterenol.

subject: isoproterenol
text: The adenylate cyclase of normal adrenal tissue was unresponsive to isoproterenol.

subject: (-)[3H]dihydroalprenolol
text: Direct binding studies with the specific high affinity ,8-adrenergic ligand, (-)[3H]dihydroalprenolol, demonstrated the presence of 0.094 pmol of specific binding sites per milligram of tumor membrane protein.

subject: (-)[3H]dihydroalprenolol
text: The tumor binding sites had high affinity for (-)[3H]dihydroalprenolol with an equilibrium dissociation constant of 2.1 nM.

subject: Adrenergic agonists
text: Adrenergic agonists competed for the binding sites in an order of potency, [(-)isoproterenol > (-)epinephrine - (-)norepinephrine], paralleling their order of potency as f8-adrenergic agonists.

subject: (-)propranolol
text: The f8-adrenergic antagonist, (-)propranolol, competed for binding, causing half-maximal inhibition of specific binding at a concentration of 6 nM.

subject: phentolamine
text: The a-adrenergic antagonist, phentolamine, and several catecholamine metabolites and precursors did not effectively compete for the binding sites at high concentrations.

subject: (+)stereoisomers of ,B-adrenergic agonists and antagonists
text: Binding was stereospecific, the (+)stereoisomers of ,B-adrenergic agonists and antagonists requiring 40- to 300-fold higher concentrations than the corresponding (-)stereo

subject: adreno-cortical carcinoma 494 membranes
text: These results indicate that adreno-cortical carcinoma 494 membranes contain ,8-adrenergic receptor-binding sites which are not normally present in membranes of adrenal tissue.

subject: catecholamine
text: These ectopic 38- adrenergic receptors presumably confer on the neo- plastic tissue the catecholamine sensitivity of its adenylate cyclase.

subject: NS1
text: Nonstructural protein 1 (NS1) of dengue virus (DENV) can stimulate endothelial cells to secrete endothelial hyperpermeability factor, macrophage migration inhibitory factor (MIF), and the glycocalyx degradation factor heparanase 1 (HPA-1).

subject: NS1
text: Nonstructural protein 1 (NS1) of dengue virus (DENV) can stimulate endothelial cells to secrete endothelial hyperpermeability factor, macrophage migration inhibitory factor (MIF), and the glycocalyx degradation factor heparanase 1 (HPA-1).

subject: NS1
text: According to a previous study, NS1 can induce endothelial cells to secrete HPA-1 to disrupt the endothelial glycocalyx, and this disruption is characterized by CD138 shedding [18].

subject: NS1
text: To further investigate the underlying mechanism of NS1-induced HPA-1 secretion, human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs) were stimulated with NS1 for various durations.

subject: many hormones
text: The biological effects of many hormones are mediated by increases in the intracellular cyclic AMP levels in the responding tissue.

subject: hormones
text: Cyclic AMP-mediated re- sponses of a hormonally sensitive tissue are elicited only by those hormones which activate the membrane-bound adenylate cyclase in that tissue.

subject: adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)
text: In the adrenal cortex, the binding of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) to specific receptors which are functionally coupled to adenylate cyclase (1), initiates cyclic AMP-mediated steroidogenesis.

subject: endogenous catecholamines
text: Compounds such as the endogenous catecholamines are normally ineffective in stimulating adrenocortical adenylate cyclase, and hence do not initiate steroidogenesis.

subject: catecholamines
text: (2, 3) have reported that the adenylate cyclase of adrenocortical carcinoma 494 unexpectedly responds to catecholamines with a /3-adrenergic specificity.

subject: adrenocortical neoplastic tissue
text: One possible explanation is that normal adrenal cortical tissue is devoid of 3-adrenergic receptors, whereas the adrenocortical neoplastic tissue possesses ectopic /-adrenergic receptors linked to adenylate cyclase.

subject: /-adrenergic receptors
text: One possible explanation is that normal adrenal cortical tissue is devoid of 3-adrenergic receptors, whereas the adrenocortical neoplastic tissue possesses ectopic /-adrenergic receptors linked to adenylate cyclase.

subject: adrenergic receptors
text: An alternative possibility is that both normal adrenal cortical and tumor tissue possess (8- adrenergic receptors, but only in the tumor are the receptors functionally coupled to adenylate cyclase.

subject: ACTH
text: Effects of ACTH (A) and isoproterenol (B) on normal adrenal and adrenocortical carcinoma adenylate cyclase.

subject: isoproterenol
text: Effects of ACTH (A) and isoproterenol (B) on normal adrenal and adrenocortical carcinoma adenylate cyclase.

subject: Basal enzyme
text: Basal enzyme activity was 8 and 25 pmol/min per mg protein in normal adrenal and tumor membranes, respectively.

text: Basal enzyme activity was 8 and 25 pmol/min per mg protein in normal adrenal and tumor membranes, respectively.

subject: (-)[3H]dihydroalprenolol
text: Direct binding techniques using the potent,& adrenergic antagonist, (-)[3H]dihydroalprenolol, were used to test for the presence of &fadrenergic receptors in normal adrenal and adrenocortical tumor mem- branes.

subject: (-)[3H]dihydroalprenolol
text:
This approach is based on the previously reported use of(-)[3H]dihydroalprenolol to identify ,-
 adrenergic receptors in a variety of non-neoplastic tissues (4-8).

subject: catecholamine
text: These binding techniques provide a direct method for assessing whether or not the aberrant catecholamine responsiveness of the adenylate cyclase in this neoplastic tissue is associated with the appearance of ectopic ,¢adrenergic receptors.

subject: (-)[3H]Dihydroalprenolol
text: (-)[3H]Dihydroalprenolol (sp act 33 Ci/mmol) was prepared by New England Nuclear (Boston, Mass.) by catalytic reduction of (-)alprenolol (Hassle Pharmaceuticals, Molndal, Sweden) with tritium gas using paladium as a catalyst.

subject: labeled material
text: The labeled material is homogeneous in six different chromatographic systems as detailed elsewhere (9) and is indistinguishable from unlabeled dihydroalprenolol.

subject: (-)[3H]dihydroalprenolol
text: The structure of (-)[3H]dihydroalprenolol is identical to that ofunlabeled dihydroalprenolol as determined by mass spectroscopy.

subject: dihydroalprenolol
text: The labeled compound as well as unlabeled dihydroalprenolol have been demonstrated to be potent antagonists of isoproterenol-stimulated adenylate cyclase (9).

subject: This membrane preparation
text: This membrane preparation has previously (2) been shown to possess the highest adenylate cyclase activity of several fractions tested from normal and tumor tissue.

subject: Adenylate cyclase
text: Adenylate cyclase and (-)[3Hldihydroalprenolol binding assays.

subject: Adenylate cyclase
text: Adenylate cyclase activity of normal adrenal and tumor membranes was assayed as previously described (13).

subject: ATP
text: Incubations were performed in a 50-IAI volume which contained 40 mM TrisHCl (pH 7.6), 3 mM MgSO4, 5 mM theophyline, 0.1 mM cAMP, 1.5 mM ATP, [a-32P]ATP (1 - 2 x 106 cpm), 5 mM phosphoenolypyruvate, 40 gtg/ml pyruvate kinase, and 20 ug/ml myokinase.

subject: (-)[3H]Dihydroalprenolol
text: (-)[3H]Dihydroalprenolol binding was assayed by incubating 0.3-mg/ml membranes with (-)[3H]dihydroalprenolol (0.7 nM unless otherwise specified) for 10 min at 370C in a 2-ml volume of incubation buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl, 10 mM MgCl2, pH 7.5).

subject: (-)[3H]dihydroalprenolol
text: The use of significantly smaller incubation volumes (< 1 ml) resulted in the complication of a significant amount of nonspecific binding of (-)[3H]dihydroalprenolol to both normal adrenal and tumor membranes.

subject: filters
text: The filters were dried by gentle heating and added to a Triton-toluene based scintillation cocktail.

subject: average specific binding
text: The average specific binding was 520 cpm in the tumor and 25 cpm in the control membranes.

text: The average specific binding was 520 cpm in the tumor and 25 cpm in the control membranes.

subject: Adenylate cyclase
text: Adenylate cyclase responses of tumor and normal adrenal membranes.

subject: normal adrenal
text: Basal adenylate cyclase activities for normal adrenal and tumor membranes were 8 and 25 pmol/min per mg protein, respectively.

subject: tumor membranes
text: Basal adenylate cyclase activities for normal adrenal and tumor membranes were 8 and 25 pmol/min per mg protein, respectively.

subject: ACTH
text: The activity of the enzyme was stimulated by ACTH (10 U/ml) in both normal adrenal (620%/o above basal) and adrenocortical tumor (480%o above basal) membranes (Fig. 1A).

subject: sodium fluoride
text: Similarly, 20 mM of sodium fluoride stimulated normal adrenal (5,400% above basal) and adrenocortical tumor (1,090%o above basal) adenylate cyclase activity (not shown).

subject: isoproterenol
text: By contrast, the /8-adrenergic agonist, isoproterenol (10-4M), caused virtually no stimulation of the normal adrenal cyclase while stimulating the tumor adenylate cyclase 220%o above basal activity (Fig. 1B).

subject: catecholamines
text: This confirms the results of Schorr and Ney (2) who demonstrated that the adenylate cyclase of adrenocortical carcinoma 494 was stimulated by catecholamines, whereas normal adrenal adenylate cyclase was unresponsive to 8-adrenergic agonists.

subject: catecholamines
text: It has been previously demonstrated (3) that catecholamines stimulate the adrenocortical tumor, adenylate cyclase, with a typical f-adrenergic specificity.

subject: B-adrenergic antagonist
text: The binding of the B-adrenergic antagonist, (-)[3H]dihydroalprenolol, was studied in membranes prepared from both normal adrenal and tumor tissue.

subject: (-)[3H]dihydroalprenolol
text: In the presence of 0.7 nM (-)[3H]dihydroalprenolol, 48±8 fmol (-)[3H]dihydro- alprenolol was specifically bound per milligram of tumor membrane protein (Fig. 2).

subject: (-)[3H]dihydroalprenolol binding sites
text: Hence, very few, if any, specific (-)[3H]dihydroalprenolol binding sites are detect- able in normal adrenal membranes under the same conditions that exist when a significant amount of binding is measured in adrenocortical carcinoma 494 membranes.

subject: binding sites
text: Experiments were designed to determine whether the binding sites detected in adrenal tumor membranes had the characteristics expected of f-adrenergic receptors.

text: Binding of 0.7 nM of(-)[3H]dihydroalprenolol to 0.3 mg proteinlml of tumor membranes was rapid, reaching a steady-state level in <5 min at 370C. Binding was constant for at least 16 min of incubation at 37°C.

subject: (-)[3H]dihydroalprenolol
text: Scatchard analysis (16) (Fig. 3) of the (-)[3H]dihydroalprenolol binding sites in the tumor membranes demonstrated that the sites have a high affinity for (-)[3H]dihydroalprenolol.

subject: dihydroalprenolol
object: its binding sites on the tumor membranes
text: The negative reciprocal ofthe slope ofthe plot provided an estimate of the equilibrium dissociation constant (2.1 nM) for the interaction of dihydroalprenolol with its binding sites on the tumor membranes.

subject: alprenolol
text: This value is consistent with the reported dissociation constant (5-9 nM) of alprenolol as a 83-adrenergic antagonist of catecholamine-stimulated adenylate cyclase in a variety of tissues (4-6).

subject: Scatchard plot
text: From the intercept of the Scatchard plot (Fig. 3) with the abscissa, the number of binding sites (0.094 pmol/mg protein) on the tumor membranes was calculated.

subject: (-)[3H]dihydroalprenolol
text: This is comparable to the number of (-)[3H]dihydroalprenolol binding sites found previously (5-8) in non-neoplastic mammalian tissues known to possess 8-adrenergic receptors.

subject: adrenergic agonists
text: The specificity of the binding sites for adrenergic agonists and antagonists was assessed by testing the ability of these agents to compete for (-)[3H]dihydro- alprenolol binding sites.

subject: adrenergic antagonists
text: The specificity of the binding sites for adrenergic agonists and antagonists was assessed by testing the ability of these agents to compete for (-)[3H]dihydro- alprenolol binding sites.

subject: /3-adrenergic
text: The binding displayed a typical /3-adrenergic specificity.

subject: Adrenergic agonists
text: Adrenergic agonists (Fig. 4) competed for the binding sites in an order of potency, [(-)isoproterenol > (-)epinephrine - (-)- norepinephrine], consistent with the potency order of these compounds as f8-adrenergic agonists.

subject: Adrenergic agonists
text: Adrenergic agonists (Fig. 4) competed for the binding sites in an order of potency, [(-)isoproterenol > (-)epinephrine - (-)- norepinephrine], consistent with the potency order of these compounds as f8-adrenergic agonists.

subject: Adrenergic agonists
text: Adrenergic agonists (Fig. 4) competed for the binding sites in an order of potency, [(-)isoproterenol > (-)epinephrine - (-)- norepinephrine], consistent with the potency order of these compounds as f8-adrenergic agonists.

subject: /3-adrenergic pattern
text: This /3-adrenergic pattern has been previously reported for these compounds as activators of the tumor, adenylate cyclase (3).

subject: f8-adrenergic agonists
text: The f8-adrenergic agonists competed for the binding sites stereospecifically (Fig. 4), the (+)-stereoisomers requiring 40-300-fold higher concentrations than the corresponding (-)stereoisomers to inhibit an equivalent amount of binding.

gic antagonist, (-)-propranolol, potently competed for
the binding sites (Fig. 5) causing half-maximal inhibi-
tion of binding at a concentration of 6 nM.

text:

consistent with the previously reported (5, 17, 18) dis-
sociation constant (3-9 nM) of propranolol for inhibi-

subject: (+)stereoisomer of propranolol
text: The (+)stereoisomer of propranolol (Fig. 5) required a 20-fold higher concentration than (-)propranolol to inhibit 50% of the binding.

subject: Structurally related compounds
text: Struc- turally related compounds, devoid of 3-adrenergic activity, did not effectively compete for (-)[3H]dihy- droalprenolol-binding sites.

subject: Phentolamine
text: Phentolamine, (±)nor- metanephrine, pyrocatechol, and dihydroxyphenyl- alanine, when present at concentrations of 10-5M, inhibited 10%o or less of the binding.

subject: (±)nor- metanephrine
text: Phentolamine, (±)nor- metanephrine, pyrocatechol, and dihydroxyphenyl- alanine, when present at concentrations of 10-5M, inhibited 10%o or less of the binding.

text: The ordinate represents the percent inhibition of(-)[3H]dihydroalprenolol binding by the specified stereoisomers of propranolol present in the incubations at the concentrations indicated on the abscissa.

subject: propranolol
text: The average specific binding in the absence of propranolol was 300 cpm and the average nonspecific binding was 260 cpm.

subject: (-)[3H]Dihydro-alprenolol
text: branes have the affinity, specificity, and stereospeci-ficity for adrenergic agonists and antagonists expected of f3-adrenergic receptors.

subject: (-)[3H]-dihydroalprenolol
text: The results of these binding studies with (-)[3H]-dihydroalprenolol demonstrate that normal rat adrenal tissue, which possesses an adenylate cyclase unresponsive to catecholamines, does not possess a significant number of 13-adrenergic receptor binding sites.

subject: catecholamine
text: By contrast, an adrenocortical carcinoma in which the adenylate cyclase responds to catecholamine stimulation, possesses ( -)[3H]dihydroalprenolol-bind-ing sites which have the characteristics expected of 8-adrenergic receptors.

subject: tumor binding sites
text: The tumor binding sites have high affinity for 18-adrenergic agonists and antagonists, and demonstrate characteristic f-adrener- gic specificity and stereospecificity.

subject: tumor binding sites
text: The tumor binding sites have high affinity for 18-adrenergic agonists and antagonists, and demonstrate characteristic f-adrener- gic specificity and stereospecificity.

subject: ,8-adrenergic receptor
text: The number of ,8-adrenergic receptor binding sites found in the tumor membranes (0.094 pmol/mg protein) is comparable to the number of sites previously found in similar membrane fractions from a variety of mammalian tissues which contain adenylate cyclase coupled,8-adrenergic receptors (5-8).

subject: catecholamine
text: Thus, these data suggest that the aberrant catecholamine responsiveness of the tumor adenylate cyclase can be attributed to the appearance of ectopic 13-adrenergic receptor binding sites which are not normally present in adrenal tissue.

subject: (-)[3H]dihydroalprenolol
text: The (-)[3H]dihydroalprenolol binding sites in the tumor membranes clearly had the specificity expected of a f3-adrenergic receptor.

subject: receptor
text: It is difficult from our data to conclude whether the receptor is a /31 or 132 subtype of ,8-receptor, although the pattern seems to be closer to the 8,I subtype.

subject: catecholamines
text: (3) previously observed a 132 specificity in the adenylate cyclase response of the tumor to catecholamines.

subject: neoplastic adrenal membranes
text: Our results indicate that the neoplastic adrenal membranes differ from the normal adrenal membranes in possessing 18-adrenergic receptors which can be detected by direct binding studies.

subject: tumor cells
text: The appearance of these receptor binding sites in adreno-cortical carcinoma 494 is presumably associated with "dedifferentiation" of the tumor cells which then allows expression of the ability to synthesize the 18-receptors.

subject: 1-adrenergic receptors
text: Spiegel et al. (20) have observed that,1-adrenergic receptors may be present in high numbers in an immature tissue such as the rat reticulocyte and may "regress" as the tissue differentiates into a mature erythrocyte.

subject: 1-adrenergic receptors
text: Spiegel et al. (20) have observed that,1-adrenergic receptors may be present in high numbers in an immature tissue such as the rat reticulocyte and may "regress" as the tissue differentiates into a mature erythrocyte.

subject: catecholamine
text: Maguire et al. (21) have demonstrated that in hybrids of rat glioma cells grown in tissue culture, sensitivity of adenylate cyclase to catecholamine stimulation is a function of the presence or absence of 13-receptor binding sites which is in turn genetically regulated.

subject: 13-receptor binding sites
text: Maguire et al. (21) have demonstrated that in hybrids of rat glioma cells grown in tissue culture, sensitivity of adenylate cyclase to catecholamine stimulation is a function of the presence or absence of 13-receptor binding sites which is in turn genetically regulated.

subject: ectopic 13-receptor binding site
text: Our results indicate that the apparent insertion of an ectopic 13-receptor binding site into the membranes of a neoplastic tissue can result in important functional consequences in the hormonal responsiveness of the tissue.

subject: ACTH
text: For example, in normal adrenocortical tissue, steroidogenesis is a cyclic AMP-mediated process which is stimulated only by ACTH.

subject: catecholamines
text: However, in an adrenocortical tumor with ectopic ,8-adrenergic receptors, cyclic AMP levels might be stimulated by endogenous levels of catecholamines, and an inappropriate steroidogenic response might be seen.

subject: unrecognized hormone
text: Hence, an endocrine tumor which is undergoing steroidogenesis in a seemingly autonomous manner might actually be responding to an unrecognized hormone which normally does not stimulate the noncancerous tissue.

subject: mechanisms
text: If such mechanisms could be elucidated in human neoplastic diseases, therapeutic attempts at blocking the ectopic hormone receptors might be efficacious.

text: Nonstructural protein 1 (NS1) of dengue virus (DENV) can stimulate endothelial cells to secrete endothelial hyperpermeability factor, macrophage migration inhibitory factor (MIF), and the glycocalyx degradation factor heparanase 1 (HPA-1).

subject: NS1
text: According to a previous study, NS1 can induce endothelial cells to secrete HPA-1 to disrupt the endothelial glycocalyx, and this disruption is characterized by CD138 shedding [18].

subject: NS1
text: To further investigate the underlying mechanism of NS1-induced HPA-1 secretion, human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs) were stimulated with NS1 for various durations.
